inventory.commentary: 16nov06 update wn2.1, added features. ahouston 16nov06 - split sense 1 into sense 1, sense5, added senses 6 and 7. ahouston

sense.name: The chemical substance, H2O, as it occurs in liquid form
sense.commentary: WATER[+entity][+substance][+chemical][-organic][+H2O] Note: refers to the -substance- in general, not a body formed of it.
sense.examples: he asked for a drink of water. You should use branch water, not soda water, to make a mint julep. Three-quarters of the Earth's surface is covered with water. (refers to the substance not a body) Water cannot put out electrical fires. There is a water hazard near the fourth hole on this golf course. (hazard filled with substance H2O) Note: the 'hazard' must be modified with 'water', unlike a lake or ocean, we don't have to say a 'water lake' or a 'water ocean'. Many patients reported their illnesses were cured by taking the waters of that spring. That's just water under the bridge now. (idiomatic usage - 'water' here is the substance)

sense.name: public utility access of H2O
sense.commentary: WATER[+state][+availability][+service][+utility][+public] Note: refers to H2O as a paid-for commodity, a public utility. Occurs with verbs that relate to mechanical processes, e.g., 'shut off', 'restore'
sense.examples: They restored the water to that neighborhood in two hours. The utility company shut off their water because they hadn't paid their bills. Do you pay for water and electricity? (refers to a service provider). Are you on city water this far out in the country? There is no running water in this log cabin.

sense.name: geographical body of H2O
sense.commentary: WATER[+entity][+form][+geographical][+body][+liquid][+ocean/+lake/+bay] Note: refers to a large geographical form (ocean, lake, river) that contains H2O.
sense.examples: They invaded our territorial waters. (refers to a region of ocean near a sovereign nation) They were sitting by the water's edge at the lake. (refers to the structural edge of the lake) John has done a lot of blue water sailing. (open ocean) The bill was intended to clean up the polluted waters of the industrial heartland. (rivers, lakes) We are sailing in uncharted waters with this new endeavor. (metaphoric extension) Commercial jets must have two engines to fly over water. (implies a large -body- of water)

sense.name: biological liquid excretion, e.g, urine
sense.examples: The child made water in his bed again last night. The doctor asked the patient whether he had trouble passing water. The woman believed she was in labor when her bag of waters broke. (sac of amniotic fluid) The child developed a large water blister on his heel from the new boot.

sense.name: fundamental element of nature according to ancient philosophy
sense.commentary: WATER[+substance][+element][+fundamental][+ancient] Note: refers to a pre-scientific notion of water, which includes powers and traits no longer ascribed to the substance, H2O
sense.examples: The ancients believed everything was made of either earth, air, fire or water. Pisces is one of the water signs of the Zodiac.

sense.name: the quality of transparency, purity, in a gem
sense.examples: We admired the water of Mary's blue-white diamond. Gems of the first water will cost a lot more than those without it. (highest measured clarity)

sense.name: a financial stock with false value, i.e., the underlying asset does not support the worth of the stock
sense.examples: The accountant determined that the company's stock was just water. John was swindled by a sleazy broker who sold him some water.
